entries.text: Jeffrey Ryan Thalhammer has opened the gates of Stratopan. (You might recall, it is the cloud-hosted version Pinto, that gives you control over all your Perl-dependencies so they will be upgraded only when you want them to. There is also a promise to get unlimited access to Stratopan for life if you sign up soon. I already have an account.
entries.title: The Stratopan Beta Is Here

entries.author: jt_smith
entries.text: JT Smith writes about the MadMongers meeting where they took a bat file (a Windows shell script) and converted it to a Perl script. It became much longer, so besides having fun, I am not sure what is the advantage here. Unless they plan to wrap some of the functionality in modules so they become reusable and then the actual script becomes short again.
entries.title: Windows Shell to Perl Program

entries.author: timm_murray
entries.text: Timm Murray, who came out from the Wumpus Cave just to attend the MadMongers meeting, has his own opinion on how much one should invest in turning a script to be platform independent. Especially when there is no immediate need to run the script on other platforms.
entries.title: Don't Get Bent Out of Shape About Being Cross Platform

entries.author: david_mertens
entries.text: 51:22 min talk by David Mertens giving some 'simple' (as in simple astrophysics :) example, and then a bunch of resources to make it easier to get started. The approach is interesting as he keeps telling why is it better to use PDL than C, but only once does he mention the advantages of PDL over pure Perl.
entries.title: Introduction to the Perl Data Language (PDL)

entries.author: yuki_kimoto
entries.text: Middleman is ruby web framework that makes developing stand-alone websites simple.  Yuki Kimoto shows an example using Mojolicious. One of the commenters points to a similar solution in Dancer, and yet another commenter points to Poet which is a modern web framework for Mason developers.
entries.title: The way to write Ruby + Middleman application with Perl.

entries.text: Tara L Andrews uses Plack::Middleware::ReverseProxyPath and a shell script to solve this.

entries.text: Perl only has one-dimensional hashes, but each value in a hash can be a reference to another hash. Or to an array. This, together with auto-vivification allows the creation of very flexible data structures.
entries.title: Multi dimensional hashes in Perl

header: Christmas is getting close and before that there is the tradition of creating Advent calendars. In the Perl world it means a series of articles, one article every day in the 3 weeks leading up to Christmas. It is a community project so you can also contribute an article or two. See the advent section for more details.
subject: Advent is getting closer
